Nothing at my old masters to be hoped for,
O Signieur du, nothing to line my life with,
But cold Pyes with a cudgell, till you help us.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Nothing but famine • rights thee: come hither Fidler,
Whad Ballads are you seen in best: be sho • t sir.

sp.speaker: Fidler
sp.l: Vnder your masterships correction, I can sing
The Duke of Norfolk • , or the merry Ballad

Of Diver ••
and Lazarus, the Rose of England,
In Creet when Dedimus first began,
Ionas his crying out against Coventry,

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Excellent,
Rare matters all.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Mawdlin the Merchants daughter,
The Divell, and ye dainty Dames.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Rare still.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: The landing of the Spaniards at Bow,
With the bloudy battell at Mile-end.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: All excellent:
No tuning as ye love me; let thy Fidle
Speake welch, or any thing that's out of all tune,
The vilder still the better, like thy selfe,
For I presume thy voyce will make no trees dance.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Nay truely, ye shall have it ev'n as homely.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Keep ye to that key, are they all abed trow?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I heare no stirring any where, no light
In any window, 'tis a night for the nonce Sir.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Come strike up then: and say the Merchants daughter,
We'l beare the burthen: proceed to incision Fidler. Song.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Who's there? what noyse is this? what rogue
At these houres?

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: O what is that to you my foole?
O what is that to you,
Plucke in your face you bawling Asse,
Or I will breake your brow.
A new Ballad, a new, a new.
hey down, down, adown.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: The twelfth of Aprill, on May day,
My house and goods were burnt away, &c. Maid above.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: Why who is this?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: O damsell deere,
Open the doore, and it shall appeare,
Open the doore,
O gentle squire.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: I'le see thee hang first: farewell my d •• re,
'Ti • master Thomas, there he stands.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.l: 'Tis strange
That nothing can redeeme him: raile him h • nce,
Or sing him out in's owne way, any thing
To be deliver'd of him.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: Then have at him •
My man Thomas did me promise.
He would visite me this night.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I am here Love, tell me deer • Love,
How I may obtaine thy sight.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: Come up to my window lov • , come, come, come,
Come to my window • y deere,
The win • e, nor th • raine, shall troubl • th •• ag • ine,
But thou shalt be lodged • ere.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: And art thou strong enough?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Vp, up, I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.l: What do'st thou meane to do • ?

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: Good Mistres • e peace,
I'le warrant ye wee'l coole him: Madg • , Madge above.

sp.speaker: Madge
sp.l: I am ready.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: The loue of Greec • and it ti • kled him so,
That he devised a way to goe.
Now sing the Duke of Nort • umberland.

sp.speaker: Fidler
sp.l: And climbing to promotion,

He fell down suddenly,
Madge with a divels vizard roring, offers to kisse him, and he f • ls down,

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: Farewell sir.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.l: What hast thou done? thou hast broke his neck.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: Not hurt him,
He pitcht upon his legs lik • a Cat,

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: O woman:
O miserable woman, I am spoil'd,
My leg, my leg, my leg, oh both my legs.

sp.speaker: Mary.
sp.l: I told thee what thou hadst done, mischiefe g • w • th thee,

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: O I am lam'd for ever: O my leg,
Broken in twenty places: O take heed,
Take heed of women, Fidler: oh a Surgeon,
A Surgeo • , or I dye: oh my good people,
No charitable people, all despightfull,
Oh what a misery am I in: oh my leg.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Be patient sir, be patient: let me binde it.

div.stage: Enter Samuel and Hylas with his head broken.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Oh doe not touch it rogue.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: My head, my head,
Oh my head's kil'd.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: You must be courting wenches
Through key-holes, Captain Hylas, come and be comforted,
The skin is scarce broke.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: O my leg.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: How doe ye sir?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Oh maim'd for ever with a fall, he's spoil'd too •
I • ee his brain •• .

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Away with me for Gods sake,
A Surgeon.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Here' • a night indeed.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: A Surgeon. Exit all but Fidler.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.l: Goe run for help • .

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Oh,

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.l: Run all • and all too little,
O cursed beast that hurt him, r • n, run, flye,
He will be dead else.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Oh.

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.l: Good friend goe you too.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Who payes me for my Musicke?

sp.speaker: Mary
sp.l: P • x o'your Musicke,
Ther's twelve pence for ye.

sp.speaker: Fid.
sp.l: Ther's two groate • againe forsooth,
I n • ver take above, and rest ye merry. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: A grease pot guild your fidle strings: how do you,
How is my deere?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Why well I thank ye sweet heart,
Shall we walke in, for now th •• 's non • to trouble us?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Are ye so crafty sir? I shall meet with ye,
I knew your tricke, and I was willing: my Tom,
Mine owne Tom, now to satisfi • thee, welcome, welcome,
Welcome my best friend to me, all my deerest.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Now ye are my noble Mistresse: we loose time sweet.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: I thinke they are all gone.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: All, ye did wisely.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: And you as craf • ily.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: We are well met Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Come, let's goe in then lovingly: O my Skarfe Tom.
I lost it thereabout, finde it, and weare it
As your poore Mistresse favour. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: I am made now,
I see no venture is in no hand: I have it,
How now? the doore lock't, and she in before?
Am I so trim'd?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: One parting word sweet Thomas,
Though to save your credit, I discharg'd your Fidler,
I must not satisfie your folly too sir,
Ye'are subtle, but beleeve it Foxe, i'le finde ye,
The Surgeons will be here strait, • ore againe boy,
And breake thy legs for shame, thou wilt be sport else,
Good night •

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: She saies most true, I must not stay: she has bobd me,
Which if I live, I'le recompence, and shortly,
Now for a Ballad to bring me off againe.
All yong men be warn'd by me, how you do goe a wooing.

Seek not to climb, for feare ye fall thereby, comes your undoing, &c.
Ex • unt.

stage.hi: Enter Valentine, Alice, and s • rvant.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: HE cannot goe and take no farewell of me,
Can he be so vnkinde? he's but retir'd
Into the Garden or the Orchard: see si • s.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: He would not ride there c • rtain, those were planted
Onely for walkes I take it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ride, nay then,
Had he horse out?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: So the Groome delivers
Somewhat before the breake of day.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: He's gone,
My best friends gone Alice? I have lost the noblest,,
The truest, and the most man I ere found yet.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: Inded sir, he deserves all praise.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: All sister,
All, all, and all too little: O that honesty,
That ermine honesty, unspotted eve • ,
That perfect goodnesse.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: Sure he will returne sir,
He cannot be so harsh.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O never, never,
Never returne, thou know'st not where the cause lyes.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: He was the worthiest welcome.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: He deserv'd it.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: Nor wanted, to our knowledge.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I will tell thee,
Within this houre, things that shall startle thee.
He never must returne. Enter Michael.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Good morrow Signieur.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Good morrow master Michael.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: My good neighbour,
Me thinks you are stirring early since your travell,
You have learn'd the rule of health sir, where's your mistres?
She keeps her warme I warrant ye, a bed yet?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I thinke she do's.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: T'is not her houre of wa • ing.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Did you lye with her Lady?

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: Not to night sir.
Nor any night • his weeke else.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: When last saw ye her?

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: Late yester night.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Was she abed then?

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: No sir,
I left her at her prayers: why doe ye aske me?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: I have been strangely h • unted with a dreame
All this long night, and after many waking • ,
The same dreame still; me thought I met yong C • llide
Iust at S. Katherines gate the Nunnery.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Her face slubber'd o're with teares, and troubles,
Me thought she cry'd unto the Lady Abbesse,
For charity receive me holy woman,
A Maid that has forgot the worlds affections,
Into thy virgin order: me thought she tooke her •
Put on a Stole, and sacred robe upon her,
And there I left her.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Dreame?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Good Mistresse Alice
Doe me the favour (yet to satisfie me)
To s • ep but up, and see.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: I know she's there sir,
And all this but a dreame?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: You know not my dreames,
They are unhappy ones, and often truth ••
But this I hope, yet

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: I will satisfie ye, Exit.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Neighbours, how do's the gentleman?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I know not,
Dreame of a Nunnery?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: How found ye my words
About the nature of his sicknesse Valentine?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Did she not cry out, 'twas my folly too

That forc'd her to thi •
〈◊〉 did s •• not curse me?
For God sake speake: did you not dreame of me too,
How basely, poorely, tamely, like a foole,
Tir'd with his joye ••

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Alas poore gentleman.
Ye promis'd me sir to 〈…〉 these 〈◊〉 .
I beare 'em till I breake • g • ine.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: But nobly.
Truely to weigh.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Good neighbours, no more o • it,
Ye doe but fling flaxe on my fire • where i • she?

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: Not yonder s •• , nor h •• not this night certaine
Bin in her bed.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: It must be truth she tel • ye,
And now I'le shew ye why I came: this morning
A man of mine being • mployed about businesse,
Came early home, who at S. Kath • ri • es Nunnery,
About day peep, told • e he m • t your Mistresse,
And as I spoke it in a dreame, • o troubled
And so received by the Abbe •• e, did he see her?
The wonder made me rise, and haste unto ye
To know the cause.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Farewell, I cannot speak • it. Exit Val.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: For heaven sake leave him not •

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: I will not Lady.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: Alas, he's much afflicted,

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: We shall know shortly more, apply yo • r own care
At home good Alice, and trust him to my counsell.

Nay, doe not weep, all shall be well, despaire not •
Exeunt.

stage.hi: Enter Sebasti •• , and a Serva • t.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l:
AT Val •• tin ••
house so merry •

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: As a pie • ir •

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: So gam • son dost thou say?
I am sure I heard it.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Ballads, and Fidl •• too •
No, but one Fidle •

But twenty noyces.
Enter Lau • c • l • t.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Did he do devise • ?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: The best devises sir: her's my fellow Launc • l • t
He can informe ye all: he was among'em,
A mad thing too • I stood but in a corner.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Come sir, what can you say? is there • ny hope yet
You Master may returne?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: H • went f • r else
I will assure your worship on my credi •
By the faith of a Travello • , and a Gentleman,
Your sonne i • found • gain • , the sonn • , the To ••

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I • he the old Tom?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: The old Tom.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Go • forward.

Next, to consider how he is the old T • m
•

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Handle me that •

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I would ye had seene it handled •

Last night sir, as we handled it •
〈…〉
Foot •• for leer • , and le •• ings • O the noy • e
The noyse we made.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Good, good.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: The windowes cla •• r • ng
And all the Cham • erma • des, in such a whobub,
One with h • r smocke half • off • other in has •
With a servingm • n • hose upon her head.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Good still,

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: A fellow • ayling out of a loop hole there
And his mouth stopt with durt.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: y'faith a fine Boy.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Here one of our heads broke.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Excellent good still.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: The gentleman himselfe yong M. Thomas,
Invirond with his furious Mermidons
The fiery Fidler, and my selfe; now singing,
Now beating at the doore, there parlying,
Courting at that window, at the other scalling
And all these severall noyses to two Trenchers,
Strung with a bottome of browne thred, which showd admirable.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: There • ate, and grow againe, I am pleas'd.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Nor here sir.
Gave we the frolicke over: though at length
We quit th • Ladies Skonce on composition
But to the silent streetes we turn'd our fu • ies:
A • leeping watchman here we stole the shooes from •
There made a noyse, at which he wakes, and followes:
The streete • are durty, takes a queene hith cold,
Hard chee • e, and that choakes him o' Munday next:
Windowes, and signes we sent to Erebus;
A crue of bawling curs we entertain'd last,
When having let the pigs loose in out parishes,
O the brave cry we made as high as Algate •
Downe comes a Constable, and the Sow his Sister
Most trayterously tramples upon Authority,
There a whole stand of rug gownes rowted manly
And the Kings peace put flight: a purblind pig here
Runs me his head into the Admirable Lanthorne,
Out goes the light, and all turnes to confusion:
A Potter rises, to enquire this passion
A Boare imbost takes sanctuary in his shop.
When twenty dogs rush after, we still cheering
Down goes the pots, and pi • kins, down the pudding pans,

The creame bols cry reveng •
• ere, there the candlesticks.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: If this be true, thou little tyny page
This tale that thou tell'st me
Then on thy backe will I presently hang
A handson new Levery:
But if this be false, thou little tyney page
As false it well may be
Then with a cudgell of foure foote long
Ile beate thee from head to toe. Enter Servant.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Will the boy come.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: He will sir. Enter Thomas.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Time tries all ther.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Here he comes now himselfe sir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: To be short Thomas
Because I feele a scruple in my conscience
Concerning the demeanour, and a maine on •
And therefore like a Father would be satisfi'd,
Get up to that window there, and presently
Like a most compleat Gentleman, • ome from Tripoly.

sp.speaker: Tom
sp.l: Good Lord sir, how are you misled: what fancie •
(Fitter for idle boyes, and drunkards, let me speak't
And with a little wonder I beseech you)
Choake up your noble judgement?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l:
You Rogue Launcel • t
•
You lying rascall.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Will ye spoile all agen sir.
Why, what a devill do you meane?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Away knave,
Ye keepe a company of sawcy fellowe •
Debosh'd, & dai • y drunkard • , to deavoure ye,
Things, whose dull soules, tend to the Celler only,
Ye are ill advis'd sir, to commit your credit.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Si • ha, sirha.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Let me never • ate againe sir,
Nor feele the blessing o • another blew-coate
If this yong Gentleman, sweet Master Thomas
Be not as mad as heart can wish: your heart sir •
If yesternights disco • rse: speake fellow Robin
And if thou speakest lesse then truth •

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Tis strange these varlets.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: By these ten bones sir, if these eies, and eares
Can heare and see.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Extre • m • strange, should thus boldly
Bud in your sight, unto your sonne.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: O deu guin
Can ye deny, ye beat a Constable
Last night.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: I touch Authoritie ye rascall?
I violate the Law?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Good M. Thomas.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Did you not take two Wenches from the W • tch to •
And put'em into pudding lane?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: We meane not
Those civill things you did at M. Valentine •
The Fidle, and the fa'las.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: O strange impudence?
I do beseech you sir give no such licenc •
To knave • and drunkards, to abuse your sonne thu ••
Be wise in time, and turne'em off: we live sir
In a State govern'd civilly, and soberly
Where each mans actions should confirme the Law •
Not cracke, and canzell it.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Lancelot du L • k •
Get you upon adventers: cast your coate
And make your exit.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Pur la mour de die •

Pur me no purs
• but pur at that doore, ou •
• irh •
Ile beate ye purblind else, out ye eight languages,

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l:
My bloud upon your head.
Exit • Lan •

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Purge me'em all sir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: And you too presently.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Even as you please sir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Bid my maid servant come • and bring my daughter

I will have one shall please me.
Exit s • r.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Tis most fit sir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Bring me the money there • here M. Thomas,
sp.stage: Enter two servants with two bags.
sp.l: I pray sit downe, ye are no more my sonne now,
Good gentleman be cover'd

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: At your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: This money I do give ye, because of whilom
You have bin thought my sonne, and by myselfe too,
And some things done like me: ye are now another
There is two hundred pound, a civill some
For a yong civill man: much land and Lordship
Will as I take it now, but prove temptation
To dread ye from your se • led, and sweet carriage.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: You say right sir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Nay I beseech ye cover.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: At your dispose: and I beseech ye too sir,
For the word civill, and more setled course
It may be put to use, that on the interest
Like a poore Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: It shall, to my use
To mine againe: do you see sir: good fine gentleman,
I give no brooding money for a Scrivener,
Mine is for present trafficke, and so ile use it.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: So much for that then.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: For the maine cause Mounsieur
I sent to treat with you about, behold it •
Behold that p • ice of story worke, and view it
I want a right heire to inheri • me,
Not my estate alone, but my conditions,
From which you are revolted, the • efore dead,
And I will breake my backe, but I will get one.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Will you choose there sir?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: There, among those Damsels,
In mine owne tribe: I know their quallities
Which cannot faile to please me • for their beauties
A matter of a three farthings, makes all perfect,
A little beere, and beeffe broth: they are sound too.
Stand all a breast: now gentle M. Thomas
Before I choose, you having liv'd long with me,
And happely sometimes with some of these too,
Which fault I never frown'd upon: pray shew me
(For feare we confound our Genealogies)
Which h • ve you laid aboord • speake your mind freely
Have you had copulation with that Damsell?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: I have.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Stand you a sid • then: how with her sir?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: How, i • not seemely h ••• to • ay.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Heer's fine sport.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Retyre you too: speake • orward M. Thomas.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: I will: and to the purpose; even with all sir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: With all that's somewhat large.
And y • t you like it
W •• ever sinne so glor • ous •

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: With all Thomas.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: All surely sir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: A signe thou art mine own • yet,
In againe all: and to your •• v ••• ll • unctions. Exit. Maides.
What say you to yong Luce, my neighbour • daughter,
She was too yong I take it, when you travelled;
Some twelve yeare old?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Her will was fifteene sir,

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: A pretty answere, to cut of long discourse,
For I have many yet to aske ye of,
Where I can choose, and nobly, hold up your finger

When ye are right: what say ye to V •••• ia
•
Whose husband lies a dying now? Why two,
And in that forme?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l:
Her husband i •
• ecov •• 'd •

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: A witty morall: have at ye once more Thomas,
The sisters of St. Albones, all five; dat boy,
Dat's mine own • boy.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Now our upon thee Monster.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Still hoping of your pardon.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: There neede • none man:
A straw on pardon: preth • e ••• d no pardon:
Ile aske no more, nor thinke no more of marri • ge,
For O my conscience I shalbe thy Cuckold:
Ther's some good yet le • t in him: bea • e your selfe well,
You may recover me, ther's twenty pound sir;
I see some sparkles which may flame againe,
You may eat with me wh • n you pleas • , you know me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Why do you lye so damnably, so foolishly?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Do'st thou long to have thy head broke? hold thy peace
And doe as I would have th ••• or by this han •
I'le kill thy Parrat, hang up thy small hand •
And drinke away thy dowry to a p • nny.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Was eye • such a wilde A • se?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Prethee be quiet.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: And do'st thou think men will not b • at thee monstrously
For abusing their wives and children?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: And do'st thou thinke
Mens wives and children can be abus • d too much?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I wonder at th •• .

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Nay, thou shalt adjur • m •
Before I have done •

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: How stand ye with your mistresse?

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: I shall stand neerer
Ere I be twelve houres old •• : ther's my busines • e,
She is monstrous subt • le Doll.

sp.speaker: Doll
sp.l: The divell I thinke
Cannot out su • tle the • .

Come, you must help • me pre • ently.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l:
Thou shalt not sl ••• no •
• ate.

No bawd to your abus •• .

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: By this light Doll,
Nothing but in the way o • honesty.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Tho • never knew'st that ro • d • I hea •• your vigil ••

sp.speaker: Tom.

Come, thou shalt help me, take heed how you v ••• m • ,

I know thou art mad, •
•• ll yong man, a brown man,

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: GOod sir go back again, and take my counsell,
Sores are 〈…〉 , nor time broke from us,
Pul'd back again by sighe • .

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: What should I doe friend?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Doe that th • t m • y red •• me ye, goe back quic • ly,
Sebastians daughter can prevaile much with her,
The Abbes • e is her Aunt too •

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: But my f • iend then •
Whose love and losse is equall ty'd •

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Con • ent ye,
That shall be my ta • ke if he be alive,
Or where my travell and my care may re • ch him,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Say he • ome b • cke

sp.speaker: Mich.

And all the care sh • now has: by which priviledge
She cannot doe her thi • violence,

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Leave disputing
Against your selfe, if you will need • be miserable
Spight of her goodnesse, and your friends pe • swasion • ,

sp.speaker: Sam,

But take heed to your s • l •••
• nd s • y • warn'd y • :
He has a p •• guy 〈◊〉 .

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l:
That • t my 〈◊〉 .
Ex • unt. Musick.

stage.hi: Enter Saylors •• nging to th • m, Mic •••• and Fra •••• .

sp.speaker: Sayl.
sp.l:
ABoard, aboard, the winde stand •
•• ire.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: These call for passengers, I'le stay, & see
What men th • y take aboard.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: A boat, a boat, a boat.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: A way then.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Whether • r • ye bo •• d friend • ?

sp.speaker: Sayl.
sp.l: Downe to the Strayte • .

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Ha, 'ti • not much unlike him.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: May I have passage for my mo •• y?

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: And welcome too.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: 'Tis he, I know 'tis he now.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Then merrily aboard, and noble friend
Heauen • goodnesse keep thee ev • r, and all vertue
Dwell in thy bosome C • llid • , my last teare •
I leave behinde m • thu • , a sacrifi •• ,
For I dare stay no l • nger to b • tr • y y ••

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l:
Be not so q •• cke sir: Saylo ••
I h • re • harge ye
By vertu • of this warrant, a • you will answer it,
For both your ship and Merchant I know perfectly:
Lay hold upon this f • llow.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: F • llow?

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: I sir.

sp.speaker: Sayl.
sp.l: No hand to sword sir, we shall master y ••
Fetch out the manacle • .

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: I doe obey ye •
But I beseech ye sir, in • or •• me t ••• ly
How I am guilty.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Y • have rob'd a gentl • man,
O •• that ye are bound to for your lif • and being •
And something of more note, but for y'ar • a gentlema ••
It shall be so, and here 〈…〉 all miser • es,
Since friendship is so cruell, I confesse it,
And which is more, a hundred of these robberies •
This Ring I stole too from him: and this jewell
The first and last of all my wealth: forgive me
My innocence and truth, for saying I stole 'em,
And may they prove of value but to recompence
The thousand part of his love, and bread I have eaten.
Pray see 'em render'd noble sir, and so
I yeeld me to your power.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Guard him to'th water,
I charge you Saylors, there I will receive him,
And backe convey him to a Iustice.

sp.speaker: Say.
sp.l: Come sir,
Look to your neck, you are like to sayle i'th ayre now.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: COme quickly, quickly, quickly, paint me handsomly
Take heed my nose be not in graine too,
Come Doll, Doll, disen me.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: If you should play now
Your divels parts againe.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Yea and nay Dorothy.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: If ye doe any thing, but that ye have sworne to,
Which onely is accesse.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: As I am a gentleman:
Out with this hayre Doll, handsomely.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.l: You have your breeches?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: I prethee away, thou know'st I am monstrous ticklish,
What do'st thou think I love to blast my buttocks?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.l: I'le plague ye for this roguery: for I know well
What ye intend sir.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: On with my Muffler •

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Ye are a sweet Lady: come let's see you cu • tsie •
What broke i'th • um, hold up your head.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Plague on't
I shall be pisse my bre • ches if I cowre th • s
Come, am I ready.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: At all points, as like sir
As if you were my Mistris.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Who goes with ye.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l:
None but my fortune, and my selfe.
〈◊〉 .

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Blesse ye
Now run thou for thy life, and get before him •
Take the by way, and tell my Cosin Marie
In what shape he intends to come to coz • n her
Ile follow at thy heeles my selfe: flie wench

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.l: Ile do it. Exit.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: My Father has met him • thi • goes excellent
And ile away in time: looke to your • kin Thomas. Exit.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: What, are you growne so corne f • d gooddy Gillian.
You will not know your Father: what vaga'res
Have you in hand, what out l • apes, dur • y heeles
That at thes • houres of night ye must be gadding,
And through the Orchard take your private passage •
What, is the breeze in your breech or has your brother
Appointed you an houre of meditation
How to demeane himselfe: get ye to bed, drab
Or ile so crab your shoulders: ye demure slut
Ye civill dish of sliced beefe get ye in.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I wy' not, that I wy' not.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Is't ev'n so Dame
Have at ye with a nigh • spell then.
Pray hold sir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l:
St. Geoge, St. George
• our Ladies knight
He walkes by day, so do' • he by night,
And when he had her found
He her beat, and her bound,
Vntill to him her troth she pligh ••
She would not stir from him that night.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Nay then have at ye with a counter-spell,
From Elves, Hobs • nd • ayri • s, that trouble our Dayries,
From Fire-drakes and fiends, and such as the divell sends,

Defend us heaven.
Exi ••

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Blesse my Master: looke up sir I beseech ye,
Vp with your e • es to heaven •

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Vp with your nose sir,
I doe not bleed, 'twas a sound knock she gave me,
A plaguy mankinde girle, how my braines totters?
Well, go thy waies, thou hast got one tho •• and pound mo • e
With this dog tricke,
Mi • e owne true spirit in her too,

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: In her, alas sir,
Alas poore gentlewoman, she a hand so heavy
To knocke ye like a Calfe down, or so brave a courage
To beat her father? if you could bel • eve sir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Who wouldst thou make me beleeve it was, the divell?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: One that spits fire as fast 〈◊〉 he sometimes sir,
And changes shapes as often: your sonne Thomas:
Never wonder, if it be not he, straight hang me.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: He • if it be so •
I'le put thee in my Will, and ther's an end on't.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I saw his legs, has Boot • on like a Player,
Vnder his wenches cloath • : • tis he, 'tis Thomas
In his own sisters cloaths • sir, and I can wa • t him.
No more words then, w • 'l watch him • thou' • t not beleeve Lance,
How heartily glad I am.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: May ye be gladder,
But not t • is way sir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: No more words, but watch him. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: VVHen comes he?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.l: Presently.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Then get you up Doll,
Away, I'le strait come to you: is all ready?

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: All.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Let the light stand far enough.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: 'Tis placed so.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Stay you to entertaine him to his chamber.
But keep close wench, he flyes at all.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You need no more instruction?

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l:
I am perfect.
Ex •• nt.
MOre stop • y • t? •• re the fiend's my ghostly • a •• er •
Old Valentine: what wind's in his poope •

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Lady,
You are met most happily: O gentle Doll,
You must now doe me an especiall favour.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: What is it Master Valentine? I am • or • ly troubled

With a salt • heum •
• alne i'my gu ••• .

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I'le tell ye,
And let it move you equally: my blest Mistresse
Vpon a slight occasion taking anger,
Tooke also (to undoe me) your Aunt • Nunnery,
From whence by my perswasion to r • deem • her,
Will be impossible: nor have I liberty
To come, and visite her: my good, good Dorothy,
You are most powerfull with her, and your Aunt too,
And have accesse at all houres liberally,
Speake now, or never for me,

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I • a Nunnery?
That course must not be suffered Master Valentine,
Her mother never knew its rare sport for me:
Spo •• upon sport, by th' breake of day I'le meet ye,
And feare not man, wee'l have • er out I warrant ye,
I cannot stay now.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You will not breake?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: By no meane • .
Good night.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Good night kinde Mistresse Doll. Exit.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: This th • ive • well,
Every one take • me for my si •• er, excellent •
Thi • N ••• ery • fal • o pat too, to my figure,
Where there • e handsome wenches, and they shall know it
If once I creep in, ere they get me out againe:
Stay, her' • the house and one of her Maids,

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: Who's there?
O Mistresse Dorothy you are a stranger.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Still Mistresse Dorothy? this geere will cotton.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: Will you walke in fo • soo • h?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Where is your Mistresse?

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: Not very well: she's gone to bed, I am glad
You are come so fit to comfort her.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Yes, I • le comfort her.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: Pray make not much noise, for she i • sure asleep,
You know your side, creep softly in, your company
Will warme her well.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I warrant thee I'le warme her.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: Your brother has been h • re, the strangest fell • w.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: A very rogue, a ranke rogue.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l: I'le conduct ye
Even to her chamber door, and there commit ye. Exeunt.

stage.hi: Enter Michael, Francis • and O ••• ers.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: COme sir, for this night I shall entertaine ye •
And like a gentleman, how ere your for •• ne
Hath cast ye on the worst part.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: How you please sir,
I am resolv'd, nor can a joy or misery
Much move me now.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: I am angry with my selfe now
For putting this forc'd way • non his patience,
Yet any other course had been too slender •
Yet what to thinke I know • ot for most liberally •
He hath confess • strange wrongs, which if they pr • ve 〈◊〉
How ere the others long love may forget all •
Yet 'twas most fit he should come back, and this wa •
Drinke that: and now to m • ca • e leave your priso • er •
I'le be his guard for this night.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Good night to your worship.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Good night my honest friends: Come sir, I hope
There shall be no such cause of such a sadnesse
As you put on.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: • aith si • , my rest is 〈◊〉
And what I now pull, 〈◊〉 no more 〈◊〉 me
Then if I plaid at span-counter, nor is my face
The map of any thing I seeme to suffer,
Lighter affections seldome dwell in me s • r.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: A constant gentleman • would I had taken
A 〈◊〉 when I took this harsh way to disturb him •
Come walke with me • i • ere to morrow night
I doubt not but to see all this blown over. Exeunt.

div.head: Scena Quarta.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: I Have dog'd his sister, sure 'twas she,
And I hope she will come back again this night too:

sp.speaker: Sam
sp.l: I have lost of purpose: now if I can
With all the art I have, as she comes backe,
But win a parley for my broken pate,
Off goes her maiden-head, and there's vindict • .
They stir about the house, I'le stand at distance. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Mary and Dorothy, and then Thomas & Maid.

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.l: Is he come in?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Speake softly,
He is, and there he goes.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Good night, good night wench.

div.stage: a bed discovered with a black More in it.

sp.speaker: Maid
sp.l:
As softly as you can.
Exit •

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I'le play the Mouse Nan,
How close the lit • le thiefe lyes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: How he itches?

sp.speaker: Doll.
sp.l: What would you give now to be there, and I
At home Mall?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Peace for shame.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: In what a figure
The little foole has pull'd it selfe together:
Anone you will lye streighter:
Ha, ther's rare circumstance
Belongs to such a treatise: doe ye tumble,
I'le tumble with ye straight wench: she sleeps soundly,
Full little thinkst thou of thy joy that' • comming,
The sweet, sweet joy, full little of the kis • es,
But those unthought of things com • ever happiest.
How soft the rogue feeles? Oye little villaine,
Ye delicate coy thiefe, how I shall thrum ye?
Your fy away, good servant, as ye are a gentleman •

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Prethee leave laughing.
Out upon ye Thomas
What do ye meane to do? ile call the house up,
O god • I am sure ye will not, shall not serve ye,
For up ye goe now, and ye were my Father.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Your courage wilbe cold anon.
If it do hang for'
Yet ile be quarterd here first.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: O feirce villaine.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: What would he do indeed Doll?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: You had best try him.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Ile kisse thee ere I come to bed: sweet Mary.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Prethee leave laughing.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: O, for gentle Nicholas.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: And view that stormy face, that has so thundered me,
A coldne's crept over't now; by your leave, candle,
And next doore by yours too, so, a pretty, pretty
Shall I now looke upon ye: by this light it moves me.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Much good may it do you sir.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Holy saint • , defend me.
The devill, devill, devill, devill, O the devill.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Dor. Ha, ha, ha, ha, the devill O the devill.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I am abus'd most damnedly: most beastly,
Yet if it be a she devill: But the house is up,
And here's no staying longer in this Cassock,
Woman, I here disclaime thee; and in vengeance
Ile marry with that devill, but ile vex thee.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Byr' Lady, but you shall not sir, ile watch ye.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Plague O your spanish leather hide; ile waken ye:
Devill, good night: good night good devill.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Oh.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Rore againe, devill, rore againe. Ex. Tho.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: O, O, sir.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Open the doores before him: let him vanish.
Now, let him come againe, ile use him kinder
How now Wench.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: Pray lye here your self, nex • Mistris
And entertaine your sweet heart.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: What said he to thee.

sp.speaker: Moore.
sp.l: I had a soft bed: and I slept out all,
But his kind farewell: ye may bake me now
For O my conscience, he has made m • venison.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l:
Alas poore Kat •
; ile give thee a new Petticoate,

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: And I a Wastcoate, Wench.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Draw in the bed Maides,
And see it made againe; put fresh sheetes on too,
For Doll. and I: come Wench, lets laugh an houre now,
To morrow earely, will wee see yong Cellid •
They say she has taken Sanctuary: love, & they
Are thicke sowne, but come up so full of thistles.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: They must needs Mall: for 'tis a pricking age grown
Prethee to bed, for I am monstrous sleepy •

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: A match, but art not thou thy brother?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Would I were Wench,
You should heare further.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Come, no more of that Doll. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: I Heard the doores clap: now, and't be thy will, wench
By th' mas she comes: you a • e surely melt f • ir • gentlewoman,
I take it Mistris Doll, Sebastians daughter.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: I take right sir: Hylas, are you feretting
Ile fit you with a pennyworth presently.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: How dare you walk so late so sweet: so weak gu • rd • d?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Faith sir, I do no harme, nor none I looke for
Yet I am glad, I have met so good a gentleman,
Against all chances: for though I never kn • w ye
Yet I have heard much good spoke of ye,

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Harke ye.
What if a man should kisse ye?

sp.speaker: Tho,
sp.l: That's no harme sir,
Pray God he scapes my heard, there lyes the mischiefe.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Her lips are monstrous rugged, but that surely
Is but the sharpnesse of the weather: harke ye once more,
And in your eare, sweet Mistresse, for ye are so,
And ever shall be from this houre: I have vow'd it.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Why that's my daughter, rogue, do'st thou not see her
Kissing that fellow there, there in that corner?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Kissing?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Now, now, now they agree o'th match too.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Nay then ye love me not.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: By this white hand Doll.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: I must confesse, I have long desir'd your sight sir.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Why ther's the Boots still sir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Hang Boots sir,
Why they'l weare breeches too.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Dishonest me
Not for the world.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Why now they kisse againe, there
I knew 'twas she, and that her crafty stealing
O • t the back way must needs have such a meaning.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I am at my small wits end.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: If ye meane honourably.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Did she nev'r beat ye before sir?

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Why do'st thou follow me?
Thou rascall slave hast thou not twice abus'd me?
Hast thou not spoil'd the boy? by thine owne covenant,
Would'st thou not now be hang'd?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I thinke I would sir,
But you are so impatient: do's not this shew sir,
(I do beseech ye speake, and speake with judgement,
And let the case be equally considered)
Far braver in your daughter? in a son now
'Tis nothing, of no marke: every man do's it,
But, to beget a daughter, a man maiden
That reaches at the • e high exploits, is admirable:
Nay she goes far beyond him: for when durst he,
But when he was drunke, doe any thing to speake of?
This is Sebastian truely.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Thou sayest right Lance,
And ther's my hand once more.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Not without marriage.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Didst thou heare that?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I thinke she spoke of marriage,
And he shall marry her, for it • eems she likes him,
And their first boy shall be my heire.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I marry
Now ye goe right to worke.

sp.speaker: Thom.
sp.l: Fye, fye sir,
Now I have promis'd ye this night to marry,
Would ye be so intemperate? are ye a gentleman?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: I have no maw to marriage, yet this rascall
Tempts me extreamely: will ye marry presently?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Get you afore, and stay me at the Chappell,
Close by the Nunnery, there you shall finde a night Pri •
Little sir Hugh, and he can say the Matrimony
Over without booke, for we must have no company
Nor light, for feare my father know, which must not yet •
And then to morrow night.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Nothing to night sweet?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: No, not a bit, I am sent of businesse
About my dowry, sweet, doe not you spoile all now,
'Tis of muh haste. I can scarce stay the marriage,
Now if you love me, get you gone.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: You'l follow?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Within this houre, my sweet chicke.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Kisse.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: A rope kisse ye,
Come, come, I stand o'thorne ••

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Me thinkes her mouth still
Is monstrous rough, but they have waies to mend it,
Farewell.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Farewell, I'le fit ye with a wife, sir.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Come, follow close, I'le see the end she aymes at,
And if he be a handsome fellow La •• c • lot,
Fiat, 'tis done, and all my state is setled. Exeunt.

stage.hi: Enter Abbesse, C • llide, and N •• s.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: COme, to your Mattin • Maids: th • se early houres
My gentle daughter, will disturb a while,
Your faire eyes, nurterd in ease.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: No vertuous mother •
Tis for my holy health, to purchase which
They shall forget the childe of ease, soft slumbers,
O my afflicted heart, how thou art tortur'd,
And Love, how like a tyrant, thou raign'st in me,
Commanding and forbidding at one instant:
Why came I hither that desire to have
Onely all liberty, to make me happy?
Why didst thou bring that yong man home, O Valentine,
That vertuous youth, why didst thou speake his goodnesse
In such a phrase, as if all tongues, all praises
Were made for him? O fond and ignorant,
Why didst thou foster my affection
Till it grew up, to know no other father,
And then betray it?

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Can ye sing?

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Yes, Mother,
My sorrowes onely.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Be gone, and to the Quire then. Exeunt.

div.head: Scena septima.
div.stage: Enter Michael and Servant, and Francis.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: HA'st thou inquir'd him out?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: He's not at home sir,
His sister thinks he's gone to th' Nunnery,

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Most likely: I'le away, an houre hence sirha,
Come you alo • g with this yong gentleman,
Doe him all service, and faire office.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Yes sir. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: VVHere hast thou been man?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Is there nev'r a shop open?
I'le give thee a paire of gloves Sam.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: What do'st thou thinke?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Thou art not married?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: By th'masse but I am, all to be married,
I am i'th order now Sam.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: To whom prethee?
I thought there was some such trick in't, you • tole from m •
But who, sor heaven sake?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Ev'n the sweetest woman,
The rarest woman Samuel, and the lustiest,
But wondrous honest, honest as the ice boy,
Not a bit before hand, for my life, sirha,
And of a lusty kindred.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: But who Hylas?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: The yong gentleman and I are like to be friends againe,
The fates will have it so.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Who, Monsieur Thomas?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: All wrongs forgot.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: O now I smell ye Hylas.
Do's he know of it?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: No, ther's the tricke I owe hi •
• Tis done boy, we are fast faith, my youth now
Shall know I am aforehand, for his qualities •

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Is there no tricke in't?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: None, but up and ride boy:
I have made her no joynture neither, there I have paid him •

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: She's a brave wench.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: She shall be, as I'le use her,
And if she anger me, all his abuses
I'le clap upon her Caslocke.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l:
Take heed Hylas
•

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: 'Tis past that Sam, come, I must meet her presently,
And now shalt • ee me, a most glo • ious husband.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: IN troth sir, you never spoke to me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Can ye forget me?
Did not you promise all your helpe and cunning
In my behalfe, but for one houre to see her,
Did you not sweare it? by this hand, no strictnesse
Nor rule this house holds, shall by me, be broken.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I saw ye not these two dayes.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Doe not wrong me,
I met ye, by my life, just as yon entred
This gentle Ladies Lodge last night, thus suited
About eleven a clocke.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: 'Tis true I was there,
But that I saw or spoke to you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I have found it,
Your brothor Thomas, Doll.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Pray sir be satisfi'd,
And wherein I can doe you good, command me,
What a mad foole is this? stay here a while sir,
Whilst we walke in, and make your peace. Exit.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l:
I thanke ye.
••• eake within.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Why, what's the matter there among these Maids?
Now benedi • ite, have ye got the bre • ze there?
Give me my holly sprinckle.

sp.speaker: 1 Nun
sp.l: O Madam, ther's a strange thing like a gentlewoman,
Like Mistresse Dorothy, I think the fiend
Crept in to th' Nunnery we know not which way,
Playes revell rowt among us.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Give me my holy water pot.

sp.speaker: 1 Nun
sp.l: Here Madam.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Spirit of earth or ayre, I do conjure thee, squeake within
Of water or of fire.

sp.speaker: 1 Nun
sp.l: Harke Madam, • a • k.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Be thou ghost that can • ot rest • or a shadow of the blest,
Be thou black, or white, or green, be thou heard, or to be seen

sp.speaker: 2 Nun
sp.l: It comes, it comes.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: What are ye? speake, speake gently,
And next, what would ye with me?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Any thing you'l let me.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: You are no woman certaine.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Nor you no Nun, nor shall not be.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: What make ye here?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: I am a holy Fryer.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Is this the Sipirit?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Nothing but spirit Aunt.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Now out upon thee.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Peace, or I'l • conjure too Aunt.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: Why come you thus?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: That's all one, her's my purpose:
Out with this Nun, she is too handsome for ye,
I'le tell thee (Aunt) and I speake it with teares to thee,
If thou keptst her here, as yet I hope thou art wiser,
Mark but the mischiefe followes.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: She is a Votresse.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Let her be what she will, she will undoe thee,
Let her but one houre o • t, as I direct ye,
Or have among your N • n • againe.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.l: You have no project
But faire and honest?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: As thine eyes, sweet Abbesse,

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.l: I will be ruld then.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Thus then and perswade her
But do not iuggle with me, if ye do Aunt.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.l: I must be there my selfe.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Away and fit her.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.l: Come daughter, you must now be rull'd, or never.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: I must obey your will.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.l:
That's my good daughter •
Exeun • .

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: VVHat a coyle has this Fellow kept i'th' Nunnery
Sure he has run the Abbesse out of her wits.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.l: Out of the Nunnery I think, for we can neither see her
Nor the yong Cellide.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Pray heavens he be not teasing.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Nay you may thanke your selfe, 'twas your owne structures.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Why there's the gentlewoman,

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Mas tis she indeed
How smart the pretty thee • e lookes? 'morrow Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Good morrow to you sir.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: How strange she beares it?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Maids must do so, at first.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Would ye ought with us, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Yes marry would I
A little with your Lad • ship.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Your will sir.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Doll, I would have ye presently prepare your selfe
And those things you would have with y • u,
For my house is ready.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: How sir?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: And this night not to faile, you must come to me,
My Friends will all be there too: For Trunks & those things
And houshold stuffe, and clothe • you would have carried
To morrow, or the next day, ile take order:
On • ly, What money you have, bring away with ye,
And Iewels:

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Iewels sir?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: I, for adornement
There's a bed up, to play the game in, Dorothy,
And now come kisse me heartily.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Who are you?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: This Lady shalbe welcome too.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: To what sir?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Your neighbour can resolve ye.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: The man's foolish
Sir, you looke soberly: who is this fellow,
And where's hi • busines • e?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: By heaven, thou art abu • 'd still.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: It may be so: Come, ye may speake now boldly
There's none but friends, Wench.
Came ye out of Bedlam?
Alas, tis ill sir, that ye suffer him
To walke in th' open ayre thus • 'tw • ll undo • h • m.
A pretty hansome gentleman: great pitty.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Let me not live more if thou be'st not cozens,

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Are not you my Wife? did not I marry you last night

At St •
Michaels Chappell?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Did not I say he was mad?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Are not you Mistresse Dorothy, Thomas sister?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: There he speakes sence, but ile assure ye gentleman,
I think no Wife of yours: at what hour • was it?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: • ' pretious; you'll make me mad; did not the Priest
Sir Hugh that you appointed, about twelve a clocke
Tye our hands fast? did not you sweare you lov'd me?
Did not I court ye, comming from this gentlewomans?

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Good sir, goe sleepe: for if I credit have
She was in my armes, then, abed.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: I told ye.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Be not so confident.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: By th' mas, she must sir •
For ile • o husband here, before I know him:
And so good morrow to ye: Come, let's goe seeke'em.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: I told ye what ye had done.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Is the devill stirring?
Well, goe with me: for now I wilbe married. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: I Hav • brought him backe againe.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You have don a friendship
Worthy the love you beare me.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Would he had so too.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O he's a worthy yong man.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: When al's tryde
I feare you'l change your faith • bring in the g • ntleman.

stage.hi: Enter Francis, and servant, and Abbesse, and Cellid • , se • erally.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My happy Mistresse too: now Fortune helpe me,
And all you starres, that governe chast desire •
Shinne faire, and lovely.

sp.speaker: Abb.
sp.l: But one houre, deere Daughter,
To heare your Guardian, what he can deliver
In Loves defence, and his: and • hen your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: Though much unwilling, you have made me yeeld,
More for his sake I see: how full of sor • ow
Sweet catching sorrow, he appeares? O love,
That thou but knew'st to h • ale, as well as hurt us.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Be ru • d by me: I see her • ye 〈…〉 him:
And what ye hea • d, beleeve, for 〈…〉
He neither dar'd, no • must oppo • e my 〈…〉 ;
And be you wife, yong L • dy, and beleeve to • .
This man you love, Sir?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: As I love my soule, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: This man you put into a free poss • ssion
Of what his wants could aske: or your selfe render?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And shall do still.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Nothing was bard his libertie •
But this faire Maide; that friendship first was broken,
And you, and she abus • d; next, (to my sorrow
So faire a forme should hide so darke intention • ,)
He hath himselfe confes'd (my purpose being
Only to stop his Iourney, by that pollicy
Of laying fellony to his charge, to fright the Saylors)
Divers abuses, done, thefts often practis'd,
Moneys, and Iewels too, and those no • rifles.

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: O where have I bestrew'd my • aith: in neither •
Let's in for ever now, there is vertue.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Nay do not wonder at it, he shall say it.
Are ye not guiltie thus?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Yes: O my Fortune.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: To give a proofe I speake not enviou • ly
Looke here: do you know these Iewel • .

sp.speaker: Cell.
sp.l: In, good Mother.

stage.hi: Enter Thomas, Dorothy, and Mary: then Sebastian and Lau • celot.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: These Iewels; I have knowne.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: You have made brave sport.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Ile make more, if I live Wench
Nay doe not looke on me: I care not for ye.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Do you see now plaine? that's Mistris Dorothy,
And that's his Mistris.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Peace, let my joy worke easely
Ha, boy: art there my boy: mine owne boy, Tom. boy,
Home Lance, and strike a fresh peece, of wine, the townes ours,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sure, I have knowne these Iewels.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: They are they, certaine.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Good heaven, that they were.

sp.speaker: Alice.
sp.l: Ile pawne my life on't
And this is he; Come hither Mistris Dorothy,
And Mistris Mary: who do's that face looke like:
And view my brother well?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: In truth like him.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Vpon my troth exceeding like,

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: Beshrew me,
But much: and maine resemblance, both of face
And li • eaments of body: now heaven grant it.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: My brother' • full of passion, I'le speake to him.
Now, as you are a gentleman, resolve me,
Where did you get these jewels?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: Now I'le tell ye,
Because blinde fortune yet may make me happy,
Of whom I had 'em, I have never heard yet,
But from my infancy, upon this arme
I ever wore 'em.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: 'Tis Francisco brother,
By heaven I ty'd 'em on: a little more sir,
A little, little more, what parents have ye?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: None
That I know yet: the more my stubborne fortune,
But as I heard a Merchant say that bred me,
Who, to my more affliction, di'de a poore man,
When I reach'd eighteen yeers.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: What said that Merchant?

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: He said, an infant, in the Ge • oway Galleyes,
But from what place he never could direct me.
I was taken in a sea fight, and from a Marriner,
Out of his manly pitty he redeem'd me.
He told me of a Nurse that waited on me,
But she, poore soule, he said was killed.
A letter too, I had enclos'd within me,
To one Castructio a Venetian Merchant,
To bring me up: the man, when yeers allow'd me,
And want of friends compell'd, I sought, but found him
Long dead before, and all my hope • gone with him.
The wars was my retreat then, and my travell
In which I found this gentlemans free bounty,
For which, heaven recompenc'd him: now ye have all.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And all the worldl • bli •• e that heaven can send me,
And all my prayers and thanks.

sp.speaker: Alice
sp.l: Down o' your knees, sir,
For now you have fonnd a father, and that father

Tha •
• ill not venture ye againe in Gallyes.

sp.speaker: Mich.
sp.l: 'Tis true, beleeve her sir, and we all joy with ye.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: My best friend still: my deerest: now heaven blesse thee
And make me worthy of this benefit.
Now my best Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Now sir, I come to ye.

sp.speaker: Ab.
sp.l: No, no, let's in wench.

sp.speaker: Cel.
sp.l: Not for the world, now, Mother,
And thus sir, all my service I pay to you,
And all my love to him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: And may it prosper,
Take her Francis • o: now no more yong Callidon,
And love her deerely, for thy father do's so.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.l: May all hate seek me else, and thus I seale it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Nothing but mirth now, friends.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Nay, I will finde him.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: What doe all these here?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: You are a trusty husband,
And a hot lover too.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Nay then, good morrow,
Now I perceive the knavery.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: I still told ye.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Stay, or I'le make ye stay: come hither sister,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why how now Mistresse Thomas?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Peace a little,
Thou would'st faine have a wife?

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Not I, by no meanes.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Thou shalt have a wife, & a fruitfu • l wife, for I finde
That I shall never be able to bring thee children. Hylas, known son agen.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: A notable brave boy.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: I am very well sir.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Thou shalt be better Hylas, thou hast 7 hundred pound a yeer,
And thou shalt make her 3 hundred joynture.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Thou shalt boy, and shalt bestow
Two hundred pound in clothes, looke on her,
A delicate lusty wench, she has fifteen hundred,
And feasible: strike hands, or I'le strike first.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: You'l let me like?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: He's a good handsome fellow,
Play not the foole.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Strike, brother, Hylas quickly.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: If you can love me well.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: If you can please me.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Try that out soon, I say, my brother Hylas.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.l: Take her, and use her well, she's a brave gentle woman.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: You must allow me another Mistresse.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Then you must allow me another servant.

sp.speaker: Hyl.
sp.l: Well, let's together then, a lusty kindred.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I'le give thee five hundred pound more for that word.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Now sir, for you & I to make the feast full.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: No, not a bit, you are a vertuous Lady,
And love to live in contemplation.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Come foole, I am friends now.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: The foole shall not ride ye,
There lye my woman, now my man againe,
And now for travell on • e more.

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: I'le bar that first.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: And I next.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Hold your selfe contented: for I say I will travell,
And so long I will travell, till I finde a father
That I never knew, and a wife that I never look'd for,
And a state without expectation,
So rest you merry gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: You shall not
Vpon my faith, I love you now extremely,
And now I'le kisse ye.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: This will not doe it, Mistres • e,

sp.speaker: Ma.
sp.l: Why when we are married, we'l doe more,

sp.speaker: Seb.
sp.l: Ther's all boy,
The keyes of all I have, come, let's be merry,
For now I see thou art right.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Shall we to Church straight?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Now presently, and there with nuptiall.
The holy Priest shall make ye happy all.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.l: Away then, faire afore. Exeunt.
